header_summary:
Gloria Zhao announced the availability of Bitcoin Core version v29.1rc1 as a significant development step, urging community involvement in testing the release candidate to ensure its stability and reliability. The binaries and source code are accessible on [Bitcoin Core's official website](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-29.1/test.rc1/) and [GitHub](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/tree/v29.1rc1), respectively, highlighting the importance of feedback through the [GitHub issue tracker](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues).

Tim Ruffing introduced libsecp256k1 version 0.7.0, focusing on maintenance improvements and API and ABI compatibility enhancements, including support for CMake to facilitate easier integration for developers. This update, detailed on [the project's GitHub page](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md), signifies a commitment to improving the library's usability and reliability within the Bitcoin ecosystem.

CubicEarth and marathon-gary contributed perspectives on user-centric feature development and the crucial concept of fungibility in digital currency, respectively. CubicEarth emphasizes assessing user demand before implementing new on-chain features, advocating for a user-centric approach over technical comparisons. Meanwhile, marathon-gary discusses the importance of fungibility and the potential impact of restricting internet access on machine-to-machine transactions, underlining the significance of Bitcoin in facilitating an efficient, automated digital economy. These discussions collectively underscore the evolving nature of Bitcoin development, focusing on both technical advancements and the broader implications for user interaction and the digital economy.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 29.1 release candidate available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v29.1rc1's binaries are now available for download.
- This release candidate aims for community feedback to refine the software before its final release.
- Developers encourage testing and reporting issues via the project's GitHub issue tracker.

recent_posts.title: libsecp256k1 v0.7.0 released
recent_posts.summary:
- Version 0.7.0 of libsecp256k1 focuses on maintenance, API, and ABI improvements.
- It introduces constant pointers for better type safety and deprecates old function aliases.
- CMake is now fully supported, enhancing build integration for developers.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v29.1 release candidate available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v29.1rc1 is now available for download.
- Release notes offer detailed insights into changes and improvements.
- Testing of the release candidate is crucial for rectifying critical problems.

recent_posts.title: On the possibility of evil covenants and implications for soft fork proposals
recent_posts.summary:
- Focus on user behavior and desires when introducing new features.
- Shift from technical comparison to evaluating user demand for on-chain solutions.
- Importance of discerning viable features that meet user needs is acknowledged.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Version 2 only for conscious living individuals
recent_posts.summary:
- Fungibility is key in evaluating digital currencies like Bitcoin and their utility.
- Proposals to limit internet use to humans ignore vital machine-to-machine transactions.
- Blockchain and cryptocurrencies enable a secure, automated economy, expanding internet utility.

active_posts.title: Make pathological transactions with more than 2500 legacy signature operations non-standard
active_posts.summary:
- BIP54's activation alongside 2500 invalid legacy sigops poses significant risks.
- A proposal suggests classifying problematic transactions as non-standard to delay BIP54 activation.
- Bitcoin Core PR 32521 targets these issues for the upcoming version 30.0 release.

active_posts.title: Revisiting secp256r1 signatures (i.e. P256, mobile HSM support)
active_posts.summary:
- P256 support could significantly improve Bitcoin's user experience and security.
- The introduction of Tapscript makes adding P256 to Bitcoin more feasible technically.
- Considering P256's hardware adoption, its integration into Bitcoin deserves fresh dialogue.

active_posts.title: Taproot is post-quantum secure when restricted to script-path spends
active_posts.summary:
- A study finds Bitcoin's Taproot secure against quantum attacks using script-path spending.
- It suggests a two-phase softfork for Bitcoin, enhancing post-quantum security.
- Quantum computing poses less threat than classical computing to Taproot's integrity.

active_posts.title: Changes to BIP-360 - Pay to Quantum Resistant Hash (P2QRH)
active_posts.summary:
- BIP-360 updates enhance Bitcoin's defense against quantum threats by modifying P2QRH to P2TR.
- The proposal avoids key-spend vulnerabilities and advances security against quantum attacks without abrupt changes.
- It introduces a plan for independent Post-Quantum signature integration, ensuring flexibility and future adaptability.

active_posts.title: Exploring Extended Relative Timelocks
active_posts.summary:
- An exploration aims to extend Bitcoin timelocks to ~10 years, driven by user feedback.
- A method suggests using bit 21 in `nSequence` to multiply timelock durations by 8.
- The initiative examines risks, use cases, and seeks feedback without altering Bitcoin's protocol significantly.

active_posts.title: Fee-Based Spam Prevention For Lightning
active_posts.summary:
- Jager and Teinturier proposed Upfront and Time-Dependent Reverse Hold Fees in the LN.
- Enhancements now ensure fee security with secrets and burn outputs to deter theft.
- New protocols feature Upfront, Hold, and Success Fees to improve LN efficiency and cooperation.

today_in_history_posts.title: BIP Proposals for Output Script Descriptors
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Andrew Chow proposes formalizing Output Script Descriptors in 7 BIPs for Bitcoin.
- Descriptors simplify issues with wallet backups and exports, including various script types.
- Proposed changes include dropping combo() descriptor and introducing metadata for future wallets.

today_in_history_posts.title: Removing the Dust Limit
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Jeremy Rubin advocates for removing Bitcoin's dust limit, presenting five reasons.
- He believes removing the limit could enhance smart contracts and privacy without spam risks.
- Rubin argues well-designed wallets can prevent fingerprinting attacks, countering main concerns.

today_in_history_posts.title: Bolt 12 Trusted Contacts
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bolt 12 enhances lightning wallets by simplifying transactions with contact lists and metadata.
- It proposes a method for selective identity revelation, integrating contact key distribution and mutual authentication.
- Feedback is sought to refine [bLIP 42](https://github.com/lightning/blips/pull/42) for privacy-preserving identity sharing in payments.
